@eldersnake@we.loveprivacy.club Yeah I‚Äôve often thought about this a lot, I I think it‚Äôs quite hard to come up with a ‚Äúposts per minute‚Äù threshold value that yarnd would limits to (assuming we dif at all).

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª On the topic of Programming Languages and Telemetry. I'm kind of curious... Do any of these programming language and their toolchains collect telemetry on their usage and effectively "spy" on your development?

@xuu@txt.sour.is I think in this case, the ‚Äúspying‚Äù is more problematic because it is proposed to be deeply embedded in the Go toolchain üò¢ We‚Äôre not talking about measuring high-level ‚Äúcounts‚Äù here, but being embedded deep within go ... commands. That‚Äôs not great for me ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic From Russ Cox: "note that if you set GOPROXY=direct, the go command still uses the checksum database to protect against supply chain attacks. If you really want the go command not to use servers, you also need to set GOSUMDB=off."

I don‚Äôt trust any public big-tech cloud company as far as I can throw ‚Äòem. Apple included.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic From Russ Cox: "note that if you set GOPROXY=direct, the go command still uses the checksum database to protect against supply chain attacks. If you really want the go command not to use servers, you also need to set GOSUMDB=off."

@ocdtrekkie Yes but think about it‚Ä¶ (not that I‚Äôm defending Google‚Ñ¢ here), if you were to implement this yourself, you would have to separate out the ‚Äúfetching a package‚Äù vs. ‚Äúverifying the integrity of a package‚Äù right? ‚Äì Put another way, you wouldn‚Äôt trust the checksum/integrity of a package from the source you got the package from (in this case Git) would you? The only wati you could do this is if the checksum was also signed with a key. Even as I write this, I‚Äôm not even sure if the GOSUMDB mechanisms can be trusted at all either, as it assumes the ‚Äúchecksums‚Äù haven‚Äôt been tampered with by Google‚Ñ¢ themselves, meaning that in a supply-chain-attack, you have to trust Google‚Ñ¢ ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
